name: how to get to a place

children.name: to show sb a house, building, or place
show
children.definition: sb sth to show sb a house, building, or other place by walking with them around it and telling them about it:
examples: Let me show you the garden.
It’s worth asking a local guide to show you the sights.
The real estate agent showed them house after house, but they couldn’t find one they liked.

children.name: show sb around
children.definition: / roundUK  to show sb the interesting or important parts of a place or building when they first visit it:
examples: She’d never been to Oxford before, so I offered to show her round.
Later, he showed Margaret all around his new house.
In the afternoon, we were shown around the Kennedy Space Center.

children.name: conduct
children.definition: to show sb a building or place on an official tour: chỉ đường, hướng dẫn
examples: conduct around
The visitors were conducted around the factory by senior managers.
An officer was sent to conduct the journalists around the shattered building.
conducted tour[C] an organized trip in which an official guide shows people a place:
We went on a conducted tour of the castle.

children.name: take sb on a tour U
children.definition: take somebody on a tour/ˌteɪk somebody ɒn ə ˈtʊəʳ/  to show someone a city, museum, house etc, and tell them about all the important or interesting parts of it:
examples: ▪ Gregory took us on a riverboat tour down the Volga.
▪ Officials were taken on a tour of the one-time maximum security prison.

children.name: directions
children.definition: instructions on how to get to a place:chỉ đường
examples: I checked the directions and turned left as I was told to.
directions to
The letter contained a wedding invitation and directions to the church.
give sb directionsLuke's given me directions to his house.
A very helpful womangavemedirectionsto the police station.
follow directionsYou can't get lost if you follow my directions.
If you follow these directions you’ll have no problem finding the house.
ask (sb) for directionsLet's stop and ask someone for directions.
get directions(= ask someone for directions )I went into a petrol station to get directions.
clear/goodHis directions were very clear and easy to follow.

children.name: to find a place you are trying to get to
find
children.definition: to find a place that you are trying to go to: tìm
examples: ▪ Did you manage to find the house without too much trouble?
be easy to find
▪ The Blue Moon is easy to find: get off Highway 78 at 23rd Avenue and go right.

children.name: find your way
children.definition: to get to a place by finding the right way to go: tìm ra lối, tìm ra đường
examples: ▪ I couldn’t find my way out of the building.
find your way to
▪ It was my first visit to New York, but I managed to find my way to their apartment without any problem.
find your own wayfind your way without anyone’s help : tự tìm ra lối
▪ Thanks, it’s not necessary for you to get up. I can find my own way out.

children.name: to find out how to get to a place
find your way
children.definition: to manage to get to a place, either by remembering the way from previous journeys, or by going the way you think is right:tìm đường
examples: ▪ Unable to find our way, we stopped at a local hotel to ask directions.
find your way to/home/out/back etc
▪ Somehow, I managed to find my way out of the forest.
find your own waywithout anyone else’s help
▪ If I take you there, do you think you’ll be able to find your own way back?

children.name: navigate
children.definition: to direct the way that a ship, aircraft, etc. will travel, or to find a direction across, along or over an area of water or land, often by using a map:chỉ đường, điều hướng
examples: I don’t mind driving but I’d like you to navigate.
I’ll drive, you take the map and navigate.
Sailors have special equipment to help them navigate.
Even ancient ships were able to navigate large stretches of open water.
Some migrating birds can navigate by the moon (= using the moon as a guide) .
There weren't any road signs to help us navigate through the maze of one-way streets.
We had to navigate several flights of stairs to find his office.
navigate by
Some birds fly at night and navigate by the stars.
Early explorers used tonavigate by the stars.
navigate your way through/to/around something
We managed to navigate our way through the forest.
navigation[ U ] the act of directing a ship, aircraft, etc. from one place to another, or the science of finding a way from one place to another
In the past, navigation depended on a knowledge of the positions of the stars.
Mechanics discovered problems with the plane's navigation system.
The fog and heavy rain made navigation difficult.
compasses and other instruments of navigation
navigational[attri]
navigational errors
navigational equipment
navigator[C] a person in a vehicle who decides on the direction in which the vehicle travels

children.name: which way
children.definition: /ˌwɪtʃ ˈweɪ/ spokenuse this to ask someone the general direction that something is in, that someone is travelling in etc:
examples: đường nào
▪ Which way are you going? Maybe we can share a cab.
▪ ‘Excuse me, which way is the Natural History Museum?’ ‘That way. Keep walking and you’ll see it on the left.’

children.name: which direction
children.definition: /ˌwɪtʃ dˈrekʃən/  use this when you when you want to know exact details about which direction something is in, about which direction someone is travelling in etc:
examples: hướng nào
▪ Which direction do we take once we reach the top of the hill?

children.name: ask the way
children.definition: ask sb how to get to/ask sb the way//ˌɑːsk somebody haʊ tə get tuː, ˌɑːsk somebody ðə ˈweɪ, ˌɑːsk ðə ˈweɪǁˌæsk-/  to ask someone the way to a place, especially when you have already started your journey:
examples: hỏi đường
▪ He looked suspicious when we asked him how to get to the border.
▪ Maggie stopped the first person she saw and asked them the way to the hospital.
▪ I’ve got no idea where we are - we’ll have to stop and ask the way.

children.name: how do I get
children.definition: /ˌhaʊ duː aɪ ˈget/ spoken used especially when you know that someone knows the way to that place: làm sao để đến
examples: how do I get to
▪ How do I get to the station from here?
how do I get there/back/home etc
▪ I’ve got her address but how do I get there?

children.name: is this the way to
children.definition: /ɪz ðɪs ðə ˈweɪ tuː/ spoken used especially when you have already started going somewhere and want to know if you are going the right way:
examples: đây là đường đến
▪ ‘Is this the right way to the Science Museum?’ ‘No, you’re going in the wrong direction.’

children.name: ask for directions
children.definition: /ˌɑːsk fəʳ dˈrekʃənzǁˌæsk-/  to ask for instructions on how to get somewhere, either before you start a journey or after you have started it:
examples: hỏi hướng
▪ Some people stopped as they passed, asking for directions.
ask for directions to
▪ I asked for directions to the town hall and made my way there on foot.

children.name: do you know the way to
children.definition: can you tell me the way to//kən juː ˌtel miː ðə ˈweɪ tuː, duː juː ˌnəʊ ðə ˈweɪ tuː/ spoken use this to ask the way to somewhere:
examples: bạn có biết đường đến ...
▪ Can you tell me the way to the harbor, please?
▪ Excuse me, buddy - do you know the way to the beach?

children.name: how to get to a place
way
children.definition: the road, path etc that you must follow in order to get to a place:đường
examples: The road was blocked, so we came back a different way.
be the way
Are you sure this is the way?
way to/into/home etc
Is this the way to Grand Central Station?
I think this is the quickest way into town.
Do you think you can find the way home by yourself?
the quickest wayShe knew the quickest way to the hospital.
the right wayAre you sure this is the right way?
the wrong wayHe had ended up going the wrong way down a one-way street.
ask sb the wayHe asked me the way to the police station.
tell sb the wayCan you tell me the way to the nearest post office, please?
show sb the wayIf you can show me the way, I’ll take you by car.
know the wayDo you know the way to Birkleigh?
lose your wayHe lost his way in the fog.
find your wayI managed to find my way home.

children.name: how to get
children.definition: especially spokenif you ask or tell sb how to get somewhere, you ask or tell them the way to a place:
examples: how to get to
▪ Can you tell me how to get to the Piazza Venezia?
how to get there/back/homm
▪ Come with me. I know how to get there.

children.name: route
children.definition: the way from one place to another, especially a way that is used regularly and can be shown on a map: tuyến đường (bản đồ)
examples: route to/from
What’s the best route to Cambridge?
take/follow a route(= use a route )
We weren’t sure about which route we should take.
the most direct route home
a direct routeThe motorway is the most direct route.
the best routeLet's look at the map and work out the best route.
the quickest/shortest routeWe took the shortest route back to the hotel.
a roundabout route(alsoa circuitous routeformal) (= one that is not at all direct )Sorry we're late. We took a rather circuitous route.
the scenic route(= a route that is not direct but goes through beautiful country )I decided to take the scenic route.
a northerly/southerly etc routeShe followed the northerly route across Spain to Bilbao.
the same routeHe had intended to return by the same route.
a different routeIs this a different route than the one we took before?
an alternative route(= one that you can use instead )Holiday-makers bound for South Wales are advised to find an alternative route.
an escape route(= a way of leaving a building or place in an emergency such as a fire )Check that your escape route is clear.
follow a routeAre we following the right route?
take a routeThey had been forced to take a longer route.
plan your routeWe studied the map and planned our route.

children.name: short cut
children.definition: a way of getting somewhere that is shorter than the usual way:đường tắt
examples: Taxi-drivers know all the short cuts.
take a short cutuse a short cut
Let’s take a short cut across the field.
Taxi-drivers know all the short cuts.
Carlos decided totakeashort-cuthome.
We were late for the game, but found a short cut through the fields.

children.name: sense of direction
children.definition: khả năng định hướng, tìm đường
examples: When night came we lost all sense of direction and were soon completely lost.
good/bad/excellent etc sense of direction
I can’t believe you got us back to the hotel - you’ve got a really good sense of direction.
Which way is it? - Ihaveno/a lousy sense of direction!

children.name: to tell sb the way to a place
tell sb the way
children.definition: tell sb how to get to/
examples: ▪ He knows how to get here. I told him the way myself.
tell b the way to sth
▪ Graham can tell you the way to Yvonne’s house.
tell sb the way out/here/there etc
▪ Excuse me, could you tell me the way out, please?

children.name: give directions
children.definition: to give sbwrittenorspokeninstructions about how to get to a place:
examples: ▪ He got into the car and began to give directions.
give sb directions/give directions to sb
▪ I’m not surprised you couldn’t find your way here if Peter gave you directions!

children.name: show sb the way
children.definition: to show sb how to get to a place, especially by going there with them: chỉ đường cho ai
examples: ▪ I’ll send someone with you to show you the way.
show sb the way to
▪ She asked a scruffy-looking little boy to show her the way to the police station.

children.name: direct
children.definition: formalto show sb the way to a place, especially by telling them where it is or pointing to it:chỉ dẫn
examples: direct sb behind/towards/out etc
A steward directed us behind the stage and towards the dressing rooms.
direct sb to sth
Could you direct metothe airport?
Go and ask the patrolman - he’ll direct you to the freeway.

children.name: to show sb how to get swh by going there with them
take
children.definition: to show sb how to get to somewhere by going there with them
examples: Let me take youtoyour room.

children.name: lead
children.definition: 1 to show the way to a group of people, animals, vehicles, etc. by going in front of them: dẫn đường
examples: I don't know the way, so you'd better lead.
If you lead in the jeep, we'll follow behind on the horses.
2[T usually + adv/prep] to take sb somewhere, by going with them:
lead sb to/through/along etc
Our guide seemed to be leading us towards a wooded area in the distance.
He led Julia through the house to his study.
She led them down the hall.
The waiter led us to our table.
Our guide led us through the mountains.
lead the way
In silence, Roland led the way back to the car.
You've been there before - why don't you lead the way?
3[ T usually + adv/prep ] to take hold of a person or an animal, or of something fastened to them, and take them somewhere:
She took the child by the hand and led him upstairs to bed.
He led the horse out of the stable.
The police officer took her arm and led her gently away.

children.name: show
children.definition: to take someone to a place, such as a table in a restaurant or a hotel room, and leave them there:
examples: show sb to sth
Could you show this gentleman to his table please.
I stood in the foyer, waiting to be shown to my apartment.
Could you show Dr Sanchez into the living room?
The waiter showed ustoour table.

children.name: shepherd
children.definition: to make a group of people move to where you want them to go, especially in a kind, helpful and careful way : dẫn
examples: shepherd sb up/along/to etc
The police officer shepherded everyone away and padlocked the church gates.
We expected to be asked to sit down, but instead we were shepherded out to an open patio at the back of the house.
He shepherded the old people towards the dining room.

children.name: usher
children.definition: to take sb to a place such as a room or building, especially as part of your job:dẫn
examples: usher sb into/to/towards etc
At the front door stood two smart young men, who ushered the guests into the house.
Smiling, Smart ushered her to a waiting car outside.
She ushered usintoher office and offered us a coffee.
Officials quickly ushered the protestersoutof the hall.

children.name: guide
children.definition: to take sb through or to a placethat you know very well, showing them the way:dẫn
examples: guide sb to/through/along etc
Sammler was a huge help, guiding me through the dangers of the city streets.
The shop assistant guided metothe shelf where the gardening books were displayed.

children.name: take
children.definition: to travel somewhere by using a particular route, etc.:
examples: If you take the road on the left, you'll come to the post office.

children.name: accompany
children.definition: 1formal to show sb how to get to somewhere:dẫn ai
examples: Would you like me to accompany you to your room?
2formal to go with sb to a social event or to an entertainment: hộ tống
"May I accompany you to the ball?" he asked her.
I have two tickets for the theatre on Saturday evening - would you like to accompany me
Children under 14 must be accompanied by an adult.
Wherever her husband went, she would accompany him.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually saygo withorcome withsomeone rather thanaccompanysomeone:

children.name: walk
children.definition: To walk sb to a particular place is to walk with them until they have reached it, usually because you are being friendly or polite, wish to protect them from danger, or to show them the way : cùng đi
examples: He offered to walk her home/tothe station.

children.name: go with
children.definition: / come with
examples: Do you want me togo withyou to the station?
Shecame withme to church.

children.name: escort
children.definition: to take sb to a place and make sure they cannot escape or that they arrive there safely :
examples: escort somebody to/into/out etc
▪The prisoner was escorted into the room by two police officers.
▪The guards escorted them to a waiting helicopter.
▪After he was sacked, he was escorted discreetly from the building by two senior managers.
escort[C orr U] a person or group who escorts someone somewhere :
▪The agreement says weapons inspectors will be accompanied by Iraqi escorts.
armed/military/police escort
▪They provided an armed escort for the journey back to Cairo.
under escort
▪The three men left the court under police escort.
